message: Python introductory literature, getting started guides, etc. printed to give to beginners
Get schedule to OSU to display on monitors outside rooms
Provide info desk with posters and flyers to hand out so they can profide info to arriving attendees
Direction posters on 1st floor should contain more info about what the conference is
bring flip charts to sprints
Yeah, knowing what we needed (VGA) beforehand would be good. I had dvi and hdmi on hand
cameras at sprints!
Mac video adaptors?
Holler loud tomorrow morning... Alex had the same problem for his talk today. He didn't have to shout very loud when Michael Trier saved his day.
My guess is that a number of folks will have an adapter
Heh,  I've got dry-erase markers... but there are no boards.
Hand-held dry erase boards and markers for sprints
So I've never run across a projector that wasn't VGA :-)
*quick
Heh do we have adaptors for VGA? Otherwise I may need to snag someones laptop for my quite talk.
Might be cool to print the knowledge level of the talks on the schedule: advanced, intermediate, or beginner.
A few 30-minute slots would be nice.  That could encourage some people to present that might otherwise not

Raffling the prizes was a bit painful, due to the number of people not present.  It'd take a bit more work, but it would be better if those present could "put their number in a hat", so to speak.  That could be physical or digital.  You could also have different hats for different types of prizes, e.g. if only certain people are interested in a license prize, it would make sure the license went to someone who could use it
Seemed there was less power available than last year, maybe because I never went into the tutorial room
ribbons or marks for people's badges who are looking for workers or looking for work

Power was also an issue for me. How about a laptop check (like a coat check) where people can drop off their device and get it powered? A few power strips and a volunteer/guard in the round room would probably work.
Get reg/checkin coded as an app (web) instead of marking off paper?
so, if anybody wants to practice, I'd be happy to mentor/help and do what I can to make sure it gets used next year
I didn't think to try the site on my phone. If I'd know that it worked well, I would have skipped conftron. Maybe that should be mentioned somewhere?
Nice to have some cheat cards for session chairs w/bios and talk summary on same sheet. Makes intros easier.
conftron: https://market.android.com/details?id=com.benvonhandorf.conftron
Oops double, looked like the first one hung from here...
The other thing that Eric mentioned would be nice is an API. He had to ask a few times for a data dump, but if there was a nice little JSON api, it could have been a bit easier
@bcostlow: feel free to add it, the site is open-source, and the earlier it gets started, the more nice things we have
small app (web?) for reg check-in instead of pencil/paper?
@bcostlow stlow: if you get really fancy, you could do JIT nametag printing too
@issackelly: Heck, we could get really-really fancy, and 2D barcode the JIT nametags, then scan everybody as they walk into the final giveaway lightning talks (but lets crawl, walk run on this)
I used conftron for quick reference & scheduling, but it didn't have locations or descriptions for talks. Maybe make mobile apps easier to develop by providing an api like codemash?
this is the codemash rest api: http://codemash.org/rest
I'd really like to see an anti-harassment policy for next year
http://geekfeminism.wikia.com/wiki/Anti-harassment_policy_resources
@velociraptors So, you might have missed a couple of nice features we had: 1) the site worked pretty well on mobile. 2) you could make bookmarks and export an ICS feed with descriptions
but yes, an API would be cool
There's some good talk about that being introduced @PyCon on their -org list, I think that we can just re-use their standards

they seem to be landing on some good ideas, using the pre-talk projection test to sort of check for objectionable material, ability to pre-screen slides (not forced, just option). Like most other things, it's really difficult to prevent a bad-actor, but making it well known that there are things that are unacceptable I think is a good policy
and eric wanted an API for registration info as well
I also hope that as the numbers grow, the inverse will be true, but I'm really not experienced in the area
@velociraptors Yeah, good point. I made some fuss about it at the time, but not at the conference
I was really pleased by the number of women I saw this year, but as the numbers grow I'm a little worried that there will be a situation that requires applying that sort of policy.
Having some power outlets routed to the classroom tables would be awesome!
was there harassment this year?
I second @brondsem on the suggestion for some 30 minute slots.
@bcostlow As usual, on the todo list :P
@velociraptors Really just something that needs to be put up on the site. I'll prod folks about that.
http://adainitiative.org/what-we-do/ can help with the policy stuff
Looks like we can just ask Pycon AU for permission to use their conduct code, it looks pretty decent. http://pycon-au.org/2011/conduct/
Most of the site is a wiki
I must say that I really liked the schedule printed on the back of the program.  It was a very useful feature!

@brondsem +1 on the painful raffle. I thought Open Source Bridge had a neat idea. They put numbered sign up sheets in front of all the items that were up for raffle. Then they picked a random number based on the number of people that signed up. This way, people were more likely to be present, and more likely to get something that interested them.

One thing I've seen a few conferences do is to put the schedule in the badge. Open Source Bridge, Plone Symposium East and re:build all used this tactic. With a smaller schedule like PyOhio, this seems feasible. Here is an example of the OSB badge:

http://yfrog.com/ki6t4bj
Another thing that OSB and re:build did with the badge is to make the person's first name large and bold. It was hard to read the PyOhio badges.
Give Brett Cannon's python-dev-in-a-box CDs to sprinters

Codemash put the schedule on the back of the badge, too. I didn't like that they were so large because it kept getting in the way, but the schedule was very useful. They didn't have names printed on them, either. Instead, registration had a wide selection of permanent markers for writing in your name/company/contact info.
I also like the Codemash badges and the ability to write my own contact info.
I think I'd rather see the names printed rather than hand written.  It looks more professional and will be easier to read.  However, I would suggest that the first name be in a larger, bold font.
Jacobian feels quite strongly about having a code of conduct: www.jacobian.org/writing/codes-of-conduct/
